newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.

text.p: PRE-SENTENCE HEARING FOR PORT ARTHUR GUNMAN
The Port Arthur gunman, Martin Bryant, will appear in the Supreme Court in Hobart today for a pre-sentence hearing expected to last up to three days.
Bryant has pleaded guilty to 72 charges, including 35 counts of murder and 20 counts of attempted murder.
Tasmania's Director of Public Prosecutions, Damien Bugg, will detail the case against Bryant and present a victims impact statement to the court.
Defence counsel John Avery, under instructions from Bryant, will enter a plea in mitigation or choose to remain silent.
Tasmania's Chief Justice, Mr Justice Cox, will hand down sentence after considering all the submissions.
CLINTON HEADS DOWN UNDER
Bill Clinton will become the third serving US President to visit Australia when he arrives in Sydney tonight.
Accompanied by wife Hillary, the President will visit Sydney, Canberra and far north Queensland during his four-day stay.
Most of the official engagments will take place in Canberra where he'll meet Prime Minister, John Howard and Cabinet, Opposition leader Kim Beazley, and Governor General Sir William Deane.
President Clinton will also address a joint sitting of Parliament and visit the Australian War Memorial's Tomb of the Unknown Australian Soldier.
COLES MYER IN FOR INTERESTING AGM
Coles Myer shareholders will meet today at the company's annual meeting.
It's been a year full of scandals, sackings and falling profits for Australia's biggest retailer which last month declared it had recorded its worst earnings performance in years.
And that revelation is likely to urge discussion on the two-point-eight-million dollar salary of chief executive, Peter Bartels.
The top order of business, however is expected to be the re-election of former Chairman of the board, Solomon Lew as a director.
Last year, Mr Lew was ousted over the so-called "Yannon transaction."
His failure to disclose his role in Yannon, which cost Coles Myer 18-million dollars, has prompted a major firm advising the board to recommend that he not be returned.
It's believed a voting block of the company's three major shareholders including Mr Lew, will be enough to get him elected.
AVIATION SAFETY STAFF IN STOPWORK MEETINGS
Senior special and middle managers at the Civil Aviation Safety Authority are due to hold stopwork meetings around Australia today.
They will consider a proposal for an industrial and political campaign to highlight what they say are serious shortcomings.
Director of the Association of Professional Engineers, Scientists and Managers, Peter Devine, says a move from individual to open plan offices was the last straw for staff.
Mr Devine says staff need closed offices so they can concentrate on the safety aspects of their work.
QLD FOOD TASKFORCE WELCOMED
Tourist operators in Queensland have backed a move by the state's health minister to improve standards in the food industry.
The establishment of a Food Safety Working Party comes after 670 people became sick in a number of recent food poisoning incidents.
It's been welcomed by the Brisbane Visitors' and Convention Bureau, which says tourist operators want to present Queensland in the best possible light.
RYAN TO TAKE WITNESS BOX AT COMMISSION
The man in charge of the State's police gets his turn today at the Police Royal Commission.
Peter Ryan will be following his predecessor Tony Lauer into the witness box.
Yesterday, Mr Lauer testified about what he indicated was official and community tolerance of vice and illegal gambling up until the early 1980s.
He also said he stood by his earlier evidence to the Commission, given almost two years ago.
Mr Lauer said then that institutionalised corruption had ended.
ELLIOT HAPPY TO CARRY TEAM-MATES' BAGS
In cricket, Australia's latest test opener, Matthew Elliot, says he was relieved and surprised to be selected to play for Australia.
Elliot, who'll make his debut against the West Indies in Brisbane in the first test which begins on Friday, says he'd have been happy to carry the bags of his new team-mates at the Gabba.
The Victorian left-hander clinched selection with a stylish 158 for an Australian 11 against the West Indians in the first innings of the four day match in Hobart.
The innings followed two impressive seasons in the Sheffield Shield, in which he's built a reputation as a heavy run scorer.
VENABLES SAYS WON'T MAKE STATEMENT TODAY

Former England soccer manager, Terry Venables, has decided not to make a statement today on whether he will take up an offer to coach the Australian team. Venables had been expected to announce his position after a meeting with Soccer Australia chairman David Hill.
A statement on the future of the Socceroo job is to be made before the end of the week.
CAPOBIANCO SAYS HE'S BEEN SHOWN NO RESPECT
Australian Olympic sprinter Dean Capobianco says his sport's ruling body has shown him no respect in its management of his drugs test case.
The International Amateur Athletics Federation has adjourned a hearing of his drugs case scheduled to take place in Monaco on Sunday.
Capobianco says the case should have been heard within 28 days, not allowed to stretch over five months.
